question.p: (This is from Review Exercises 9 and 10 of Chapter 18).
One hundred draws are made at random with replacement from a box with ninety-nine tickets marked "0" and one ticket marked "1". True or false, and explain:

ol.li: The sum will be around 1, give or take 1 or so.
There is about a 68% chance that the sum will be in the range 0 to 2.

question.p: Now, suppose that instead of drawing 100 draws from this box with replacement, you draw a ten thousand times with replacement. True or false, and explain:

ol.li: The sum will be around 100, give or take 10 or so.
There is about a 68% chance that the sum will be in the range 90 to 110.

solution.p: If you draw n times from the box, then the SD of the sum is sqrt((1/100)*(99/100)*n). So when you draw 100 times, the SD is 0.99, and when you draw 10000 times, the SD is 9.9. And of course, the expected value of the sum is n * 1/100, so you expect the sum to be 1 and 100 when you draw 100 and 10000 times, respectively.
Thus, (a) is correct for both 100 and 10000 draws, since the quoted ranges are the expected values of the draws plus or minus the SDs.

(b) is based on the idea of using a normal approximation. When you draw 10000 times, this normal approximation is reasonable, since the expected number of draws is so large. But when you draw only 100 times, the expected number of draws is too small to use the normal approximation. So for 100 draws, (b) is false, but for 10000 draws, (b) is true.
Please grade this question out of six points. Award one point each for getting each of the four parts correct, and award the remaining two points for correct explainations

hw.question:
(Chapter 23, Special Review Exercise 28) NAEP (National Assessment of Educational Progress) periodically tests scientific knowledge in U.S. schools. In a test administered to 12th graders, there was one straightforward question about reading a thermometer. Only 64% of the students who were tested could answer this question correctly. The superintendent of education in a certain state cannot believe these data. To check, he takes a simple random sample of 100 high schools in the state, and tests 10 randomly selected students from grade 12 in each school. 661 out of the 1,000 students who take the test, or 66.1%, can do the problem. With the information above, can you put a standard error on the 66.1%? Find the SE, or say why this can't be done.
Sample Correct Solution
This can't be done with the information given, because it is a cluster sample. That is, the 1,000 students' answers to the question are not independent, since some of them came from the same school and thus are likely to have been educated similarly. The following is not part of the question asked (and thus not worth any points), but is also worth noting. Since the superintendent only sampled students from his state, even if he did somehow obtain a sample of independent students and thus could compute a SE and thus a confidence interval for his estimate, that confidence interval would only apply within his state. Therefore he couldn't really compare it to the (presumably national) figure of 64%.
Grading Rubric
Please grade this question out of 6 points following these guidelines.
3 points for saying the SE cannot be computed
3 points for stating that it is a cluster sample, or explaining why the observations aren't independent
Feel free to give partial credit or to use your good judgement if you think the case merits it

question.p: (Chapter 23, Special Review Exercise 30) A survey research company uses random digit dialing. They have a contract, to estimate the percentage of people watching Spanish-language television in several Southwestern cities. They took a sample of 1,000 in Austin, Texas--which has about 600,000 residents. They are satisfied with the accuracy of the estimates for Austin. Dallas has about twice the population of Austin, but similar demographics. To get about the same accuracy in Dallas as in Austin, how large a sample size should the company use?
